title: The rise of the Ottoman Empire - Mostafa Minawi

multiple-choice.question: Who established a small beylik, or principality, in what is now Turkey in the late 13th century?

options.label: C
options.text: A mixture of strategic political alliances and military conflicts

At its peak, the Ottoman Empire stretched from which regions?

options.label: A
options.text: Hungary to the Persian Gulf, from the Horn of Africa to the Crimean Peninsula

options.label: B
options.text: Turkey to the Middle East, from North Africa to Eastern Europe

options.label: C
options.text: Europe to Asia, from the Mediterranean to the Black Sea

options.label: D
options.text: The Balkans to Anatolia, from the Aegean to the Mediterranean

options.label: B
options.text: Her intelligence and martial arts skills

options.label: B
options.text: Because of her blinding splendor and beauty

options.label: C
options.text: Because of her family's wealth and status

options.label: D

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: That he had only a year to live

options.label: D

options.label: D

title: Do personality tests work? - Merve Emre

multiple-choice.question: Who developed the Myers-Briggs Type Indicator (MBTI) in 1942?

options.label: B
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Isabel Briggs Myers

options.label: C
options.text: Isabel Briggs Myers and Carl Jung

options.label: D
options.text: Katherine Cook Briggs and Sigmund Freud

multiple-choice.question: What is a major criticism of personality tests, including the MBTI?

options.label: A
options.text: They are too expensive to administer.

options.label: B
options.text: They are not widely used by individuals and companies.

options.label: C
options.text: They do not actually reveal truths about personality.

options.label: D
options.text: They are too time-consuming to complete.

multiple-choice.question: What is a problem with the way personality tests are constructed?

options.label: A
options.text: They are based on a single set of metrics to define personality.

options.label: B
options.text: They are based on different sets of metrics to define personality.

options.label: C
options.text: They are only used by individuals, not by companies or schools.

multiple-choice.question: Why can self-reported personality tests be unreliable?

options.label: A
options.text: Because people may lie on the test.

options.label: B
options.text: Because people may not understand the questions.

options.label: C
options.text: Because people subconsciously aim to please and may show bias in their answers.

multiple-choice.question: According to the transcript, what is a limitation of the MBTI?

options.label: A
options.text: It allows participants to choose multiple answers for each question.

options.label: B
options.text: It forces participants to choose between two options, even if they value both.

options.label: C
options.text: It is not widely used by companies and schools.

options.label: D
options.text: It is too expensive to administer.

multiple-choice.question: What did a study find about the consistency of MBTI results?

options.label: A
options.text: Nearly all people who take the test a second time get assigned the same type.

options.label: B
options.text: Nearly half of people who take the test a second time get assigned a different type.

options.label: C
options.text: The test results are always consistent, no matter how many times the test is taken.

options.label: D
options.text: The test results are never consistent, no matter how many times the test is taken.

multiple-choice.question: How has the definition of introversion changed over time?

options.label: B
options.text: It originally meant sticking to one's principles, but now means shyness.

options.label: C
options.text: It originally meant sticking to one's principles, but now means finding alone time restorative.

options.label: D
options.text: It has always meant finding alone time restorative.

multiple-choice.question: According to research, what happens to personality over time?

options.label: A
options.text: It remains completely stable and unchanged.

options.label: B
options.text: It shifts during key periods, such as school years or when starting work.

options.label: C
options.text: It changes completely every few years.

options.label: D
options.text: It only changes in response to major life events.

multiple-choice.question: How are personality tests often used by schools and companies?

options.label: A
options.text: To advise students on what to study and what jobs to pursue, and to decide who to hire and for what positions.

multiple-choice.question: What is a potential consequence of using personality tests to make decisions about education and employment?

options.label: A
options.text: People may be encouraged to pursue careers that are a good fit for them.

options.label: B
options.text: People may be deprived of opportunities they would excel at, or discouraged from considering certain paths.

options.label: C
options.text: People may be more likely to change careers later in life.

options.label: D
options.text: People may be more likely to start their own businesses.

title: 10 ways to have a better conversation - Celeste Headlee

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, what is the current state of conversations in the world?

options.label: A
options.text: People are more open to listening to opposing views.

options.label: B
options.text: Conversations are becoming more polite and less argumentative.

options.label: C
options.text: The world is more polarized and divided than ever before.

options.label: D
options.text: Technology has improved the way people communicate.

multiple-choice.question: What is the result of people not listening to each other, according to the speaker?

options.label: A
options.text: They become more empathetic and understanding.

options.label: B
options.text: They are more likely to compromise and find common ground.

options.label: C
options.text: They make decisions based on what they already believe.

options.label: D
options.text: They become more confident in their opinions.

multiple-choice.question: What is the main reason why the speaker believes conversational competence is overlooked?

options.label: A
options.text: People are too busy with their daily lives.

options.label: B
options.text: Technology has made face-to-face communication unnecessary.

options.label: C
options.text: Kids spend more time engaging with ideas through screens than practicing interpersonal communication skills.

options.label: D
options.text: It is not considered an important skill in the 21st century.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on how to show you're paying attention in a conversation?

options.label: A
options.text: Repeat back what you just heard or summarize it.

options.label: B
options.text: Look the person in the eye and nod.

options.label: C
options.text: Think of interesting topics to discuss in advance.

options.label: D
options.text: Don't try to show you're paying attention, just pay attention.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's first rule for having better conversations?

options.label: B
options.text: It helps to build a connection with the other person.

options.label: C
options.text: It is never the same and can come across as insensitive.

options.label: D
options.text: It is a way to prove how amazing you are.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's advice on what to do if you don't know something in a conversation?
What is the speaker's eighth rule for having better conversations?

options.label: C
options.text: Try to be the center of attention.

options.label: D
options.text: Don't listen to the other person.

multiple-choice.question: According to the speaker, why do people often not listen to each other?

options.label: A
options.text: They are not interested in the conversation.

options.label: B
options.text: They would rather talk and be in control.

options.label: C
options.text: They are distracted and their minds wander.

multiple-choice.question: What is the speaker's final rule for having better conversations?

options.label: B
options.text: Be brief and interested in other people.

options.label: C

options.text: A type of white blood cell that fights pathogens

options.label: B
options.text: A mechanism that traps invaders and carries them toward the mouth

options.label: C
options.text: A type of bacteria that causes pneumonia

options.label: D
options.text: A type of virus that causes pneumonia

options.label: C
